title: Group terms with common factors
text: The first step is to check if there is a GCF among all terms. If there isn't then separate the equation into the terms with like variables. In this case, we would separate the first two terms from the second two.
speech: The first step is to check if there is a GCF among all terms. If there isn't then separate the equation into the terms with like variables. In this case, we would separate the first two terms from the second two.
pacedSpeech: The first step is to check if there is a GCF among all terms. If there isn't then separate the equation into the terms with like variables. In this case, we would separate the first two terms from the second two.

title: Factoring
text: The next step is to factor the GCF from the first two terms and second two terms.
speech: The next step is to factor the GCF from the first two terms and second two terms.
pacedSpeech: The next step is to factor the GCF from the first two terms and second two terms.

title: Factoring
text: What is the GCF of the first two terms?

title: Factoring
text: What is the GCF of the second two terms?
speech: What is the GCF of the second two terms?

title: Factoring
text: Notice that each term has a common factor of $$x+8$$. Factor out the common factor.
speech: Notice that each term has a common factor of  x plus 8 . Factor out the common factor.
pacedSpeech: Notice that each term has a common factor of   x plus 8

title: Factoring
speech: This leaves you with  parentheses a plus 7,  times, parentheses b plus 8,
pacedSpeech: This leaves you with    a plus 7,  times,  b plus 8,
